linkTarget.anchoringText: The area of study is located in the Sacha field, Oriente Basin, in Ecuador. This area in which four horizontal wells were drilled at Platform Sacha-470 targeting to the Lower "U" Sandstone has 2D seismic data with poor quality vertical resolution (Fig. 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Seismic Line W-E crossing through Pad Sacha 470

formatted-caption.caption-text: Seismic Line W-E crossing through Pad Sacha 470

linkTarget.anchoringText: The importance of an accurate landing within the target sandstone is crucial when navigating within the zone of interest. Well correlations are essential to performing an adequate landing because they allow comparison and identification of lithological aspects between correlation wells and the target (Fig. 2) well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Stratigraphic correlation referred to as Upper "U" Sandstone top

formatted-caption.caption-text: Stratigraphic correlation referred to as Upper "U" Sandstone top

linkTarget.anchoringText: Logging results from zones where the bar/cannel system is present reveal predominant shapes of gamma ray curves are box and funnel (is tuned up); RHOB and NPHI crossing curves show a good quality reservoir, and cuttings reveal a coarse good porosity sandstone (Fig. 3).
With geological studies and knowing the existing hydrocarbon potential in the field, it was decided to drill in the flank of the structure (Fig. 4).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Structural map at the top of the Lower "U" Sandstone; the Platform Sacha 470 is located at the east flank of the structure

formatted-caption.caption-text: Structural map at the top of the Lower "U" Sandstone; the Platform Sacha 470 is located at the east flank of the structure

linkTarget.anchoringText: However, during the lateral section drilling stage, the depth of investigation of the sensors is essential, which allows a proactive geosteering operation (Fig. 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Graphic scheme for the anticipation distance calculation between a LWD tool and a bed boundary based on Lee C. 2005. Refining Geology with the Bit: An Innovative Approach to Well Design and Geosteering

formatted-caption.caption-text: Graphic scheme for the anticipation distance calculation between a LWD tool and a bed boundary based on Lee C. 2005. Refining Geology with the Bit: An Innovative Approach to Well Design and Geosteering

linkTarget.anchoringText: To land at the desired point, the thickness of the previous strata, drilling parameters, and particularly the gamma ray readings and bottom cuttings were considered (Fig. 6).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Landing point 7 ft TVD below the Lower "U" Sandstone top. 80% sandstone is reported

formatted-caption.caption-text: Landing point 7 ft TVD below the Lower "U" Sandstone top. 80% sandstone is reported

linkTarget.anchoringText: In this zone, the presence of kaolin was encountered for the cuttings, which caused drastic decrease in terms of quality of the logs (Fig. 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Continuing the directional plan, within the reservoir, an unexpected change was observed

formatted-caption.caption-text: Continuing the directional plan, within the reservoir, an unexpected change was observed

linkTarget.anchoringText: From this point until the end of the well, the trajectory of the well was modified proactively. With the real-time information, the geosteering team can perform necessary recommendations to avoid exiting the well mainly to the base (Figs. 8 and 9) and then to the top of the reservoir.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Distance to bed boundary calculation. The recommendation to increase well inclination, based on azimuthal responses, allowed the well to stay within the reservoir and avoid an imminent exit to the base

formatted-caption.caption-text: Distance to bed boundary calculation. The recommendation to increase well inclination, based on azimuthal responses, allowed the well to stay within the reservoir and avoid an imminent exit to the base

linkTarget.anchoringText: From this point until the end of the well, the trajectory of the well was modified proactively. With the real-time information, the geosteering team can perform necessary recommendations to avoid exiting the well mainly to the base (Figs. 8 and 9) and then to the top of the reservoir.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Distance to bed boundary calculation. Well total depth (TD) with 60% of the longitude of the well within good sandstone characteristics. Notice the geosignal and azimuthal resistivities behavior show with anticipation the contrast of resistivities to the top and base

formatted-caption.caption-text: Distance to bed boundary calculation. Well total depth (TD) with 60% of the longitude of the well within good sandstone characteristics. Notice the geosignal and azimuthal resistivities behavior show with anticipation the contrast of resistivities to the top and base

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figs. 10 through 12 present results from the production data of the four horizontal and the two directional wells (Updated July 2015).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Oil-water production ratio; directional wells targeting the Lower "U" Sandstone; it is important to mention that Well Sacha 476 was drilled in a different direction than the rest of wells (closer to the main structure) (refer to Fig. 13)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil-water production ratio; directional wells targeting the Lower "U" Sandstone; it is important to mention that Well Sacha 476 was drilled in a different direction than the rest of wells (closer to the main structure) (refer to Fig. 13)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figs. 10 through 12 present results from the production data of the four horizontal and the two directional wells (Updated July 2015).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Oil-water production ratio of the two first horizontal wells drilled in the pad; wells targeting the Lower "U" Sandstone

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil-water production ratio of the two first horizontal wells drilled in the pad; wells targeting the Lower "U" Sandstone

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figs. 10 through 12 present results from the production data of the four horizontal and the two directional wells (Updated July 2015).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Oil-water production ratio of the two last horizontal wells drilled in the pad; wells targeting the Lower "U" Sandstone

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil-water production ratio of the two last horizontal wells drilled in the pad; wells targeting the Lower "U" Sandstone

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the absence of oil water contact in the directional wells, and taking into account the tendency of the oil-water ratio for the horizontal wells, the hypothesis that the water saturation is concentrated north of the pad is valid (Fig. 13).

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Oil water ratio tendency of horizontal

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil water ratio tendency of horizontal

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Monthly production of two directional wells compared to four horizontal wells. Notice that, after drilling the horizontal wells, production increased by three times

formatted-caption.caption-text: Monthly production of two directional wells compared to four horizontal wells. Notice that, after drilling the horizontal wells, production increased by three times
